properties.Title: Fort Niagara
properties.Explanatory_text: Strategically important British fort, controlling access to the Great Lakes. Site of diplomacy with Great Lakes-based Indigenous nations.

properties.Title: Detroit
properties.Explanatory_text: Strategically important British fort. Site of negotiations between Lieutenant Governor Henry Hamilton, White Eyes, and William Wilson.

properties.Title: Philadelphia
properties.Explanatory_text: Site of the Continental Congress.

properties.Title: Lancaster
properties.Explanatory_text: Yeates' place of residence. This marker shows the location of his home.

properties.Title: Tinian
properties.Explanatory_text: Home of James Burd, Yeates' father-in-law.

properties.Title: Carlisle
properties.Explanatory_text: Yeates stopped here on his way to Pittsburgh. Site of Fort Carlisle.

properties.Title: Shippensburg
properties.Explanatory_text: Named for Sarah Yeates' maternal grandfather, Edward Shippen.

properties.Title: Fort Pitt
properties.Explanatory_text: Strategically important American fort. Site of trade and diplomacy with Ohio Valley Indigenous nations.

properties.Title: Pluggy's Town
properties.Explanatory_text: Home to a coalition of Mingo, Delaware, Mohawk, Shawnee, and Wyandot people, allied with the British and militantly opposed to settler rule. Named for its leader, Plukkemehnotee or Pluggy.

properties.Title: Tuscarawas
properties.Explanatory_text: A Delaware village.

properties.Title: Goschachgunk
properties.Subtitle: Coshocton, Cooshoking, Coochocking, Cushacking, Cooshaughking
properties.Explanatory_text: Built in 1775 and modeled after Moravian mission towns, including streets laid out on a grid system. Major center of diplomacy. Yeates' allies frequently sent messages from here.

properties.Title: Fort Randolph
properties.Explanatory_text: American fort meant to defend the western frontier. US-allied Shawnee chief Cornstalk was held hostage and murdered here in 1777.

properties.Title: Sandusky
properties.Subtitle: Sanduske, Sanduske Creek
properties.Explanatory_text: Site of trade between British and Wyandot peoples.

properties.Title: Wheeling
properties.Explanatory_text: American settlement and site of Fort Henry.

properties.Title: Kanawha
properties.Explanatory_text: Approximate site of two American settlements, referred to in the Yeates papers as Big Kanawha and Little Kanawha.

properties.Title: Kittaning
properties.Explanatory_text: Former site of a village of Delaware, Cayuga, Seneca, and Shawnee people. Destroyed by the British during the French and Indian War, and subsequently used as a military camp by the Americans.

properties.Title: Presque Isle
properties.Explanatory_text: A British fort here was destroyed by Seneca, Ottawa, Huron, and Chippewa people during Pontiac's War. Mentioned as a potential site of American military operations.

properties.Title: Le Boeuf
properties.Explanatory_text: A British fort here was destroyed during Pontiac's War. Mentioned as a potential site of American military operations.

properties.Title: Logstown
properties.Explanatory_text: Originally a Shawnee village; later home to Six Nations, Wyandot, Delaware, and other Indigenous peoples, as well as some British and French traders. Destroyed during the French and Indian war.

properties.Title: Shackamaxon
properties.Explanatory_text: A sacred site for the Delaware people. Also believed to be the site of the treaty between William Penn and the Delaware signed in 1682.

properties.Title: Gekelemukpechunk
properties.Subtitle: Newcomerstown
properties.Explanatory_text: Delaware town established by Netawatwes (Newcomer), an important political leader.

properties.Title: Hell Town
properties.Explanatory_text: An abandoned Mingo village, resettled by the Delaware in the 1770s. (A letter from William Wilson refers to "new Hell Town," which may indicate a different location.)

properties.Title: Schonbrunn
properties.Explanatory_text: Moravian mission town with close ties to the local Delaware community. While not mentioned by name, Schoenbrunn was likely one of the "Moravian towns" referenced in the Yeates papers.

properties.Title: Lichtenau
properties.Explanatory_text: Moravian mission built downriver from, and with close ties to, Goschachgunk. Some Delawares and Mohicans, many of them converts to Christianity, lived here. While not mentioned by name, Lichtenau was likely one of the "Moravian towns" referenced in the Yeates papers.

properties.Title: Gnadenhutten
properties.Explanatory_text: Moravian mission with a large population of Delaware converts, many of whom were killed by white settlers in the 1782 Gnadenhutten Massacre. While not mentioned by name, Schoenbrunn was likely one of the "Moravian towns" referenced in the Yeates papers.

properties.Title: Fort Stanwix
properties.Explanatory_text: Site of a 1768 treaty between the Six Nations and the British, giving up Kentucky and most of what is now West Virginia to the British while forbidding colonists from settling west of the Ohio River.

properties.Title: German Flatts
properties.Explanatory_text: American settlement build on land purchased from the Mohawk. Mentioned as possible site for negotiations between Americans and the Six Nations sometime in fall 1776.

properties.Title: Stockbridge
properties.Explanatory_text: A "praying town" established by British missionaries and inhabited by Mohicans who converted to Christianity. During the Treaty Council, the Stockbridge Mohicans sent a wampum belt declaring their intent to go to war with the British. Some of these men formed the Stockbridge militia, many of whom were killed by British forces.

properties.Title: Fort Oswegatchie
properties.Explanatory_text: British-controlled fort mentioned as the site of a treaty council with Chippewa, Ottawa, and Seneca peoples.

properties.Title: Maquaqua
properties.Explanatory_text: Likely site of the "Wiandot Town" mentioned in the Yeates papers.

properties.Title: Shawnee Towns
properties.Explanatory_text: Exact coordinates are difficult to find, but this area was the likely site of the "Shawanese Towns" referenced in the Yeates papers. These included Lower Shawneetown (a center of trade and diplomacy relocated during the French and Indian War) and Cornstalk Town (named for the Shawnee political leader).

properties.Title: Captain Johnny's Town
properties.Explanatory_text: Named for Kekewepelethy (Captain Johnny), a Shawnee political leader who attended the 1776 Treaty Council and initially sought neutrality in the war, but later fought against the Americans. Approximate location.

properties.Title: Fincastle Town
properties.Explanatory_text: Mentioned as the source of intelligence on a Cherokee and Shawnee attack on American settlers. Named for Lord Dunmore's eldest son.

properties.Title: White Eyes' Town
properties.Explanatory_text: Established by and named for the Delaware political leader.

properties.Title: Kickapoo Grand Village
properties.Explanatory_text: Possible site of the "Kickapoo Town in the Shawanese Nation" mentioned in the Yeates papers.

properties.Title: Mingo Town
properties.Explanatory_text: Likely site of (at least one of) the "mingo towns" referenced in the Yeates papers.

properties.Title: Mingo Flats
properties.Explanatory_text: Likely site of (at least one of) the "mingo towns" referenced in the Yeates papers.
